chunks.section_title: To the Shareholders of Berkshire Hathaway Inc.
chunks.start_anchor:
To the Shareholders of Berkshire Hathaway Inc.:

Our gain in net worth during 1984 was $152.6 million, or
$133 per share. This sounds pretty good but actually its
mediocre. Economic gains must be evaluated by comparison with
chunks.end_anchor:
Levitz,
in that year, operated at a gross margin of 44.4% (that is, on
average, customers paid it $100 for merchandise that had cost it
$55.60 to buy). The gross margin at NFM is not much more than
half of that. NFMs low mark-ups are possible because of its
exceptional efficiency: operating expenses (payroll, occupancy,
advertising, etc.) are about 16.5% of sales versus 35.6% at
Levitz.
chunks.contextual_summary: This chunk opens the letter with a performance overview, detailing Berkshire's net worth gain in 1984 and comparing it to historical returns. It includes a detailed financial table breaking down earnings by business segment and explains the accounting treatment of special distributions from GEICO and General Foods. The chunk also discusses the strategic importance of share repurchases and introduces Nebraska Furniture Mart with a comparison to Levitz Furniture's margins, illustrating Berkshire's focus on operational efficiency and shareholder value.
chunks.next_context: The next section will continue the discussion of Nebraska Furniture Mart's business and management.
chunks.principle_statement: Share repurchases at prices below intrinsic value create significant shareholder wealth and demonstrate management's alignment with owners.
